: If there’s a place where the most creative, smart, and interesting people flock to, Lesley is right in the center of it. Cambridge forms a nexus of research and scholarship that’s unmatched anywhere in the world.
Stroll across the Charles River to Boston
Get to know vibrant Harvard Square, just a few minutes from campus
Obsessive shoppers will love browsing the storefronts in Harvard Square
It's easy to travel through the city, on foot or by bike
There's always something happening here, from live music to performance art
Local music venues, like the Sinclair, make for amazing culture and nightlife
Get from point A to point B easily on the subway (known as the T)
A hub for students from around the world, Harvard Square is always buzzing with energy
A nexus for education and the arts, Cambridge has endless museums and galleries to explore
And let's not forget our famous neighbor—Harvard University
Grab something quick and delicious at the food trucks parked minutes from campus

Get started on achieving your goals. Apply, visit, or talk to us today.

You’ve found the program for you. Let’s take the next steps. Come to our campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts to experience the place. Get your application going. Find ways to finance your education. Whatever you need, we’re here to help.
At this stage you know Lesley is for you. You're getting ready to apply and you want to make sure you stand out. One surefire way to do that is to read our application guides.
Ready to learn about costs and how to pay for a Lesley education? You've come to the right place. Education is an investment in your future, and we're here to set you on the path to big things.
Pursuing your education is a big step. Our admissions counselors and advisors are education experts, ready to guide you through every step of the way.
Tour our Cambridge campus, sit in on a class, get a feel for the daily atmosphere, talk to students and faculty members, and get answers to your questions.
Now that you've been accepted to Lesley University, all that's left to do is to let us know you're coming.

At this stage you know Lesley is for you. You're getting ready to apply and you want to make sure you stand out. One surefire way to do that is to read our application guides.

So, you’ve decided to apply to Lesley. It’s an exciting feeling, but also a bit nerve-wracking. We totally get it. That’s why we’ve put together easy-to-follow application guides for our undergraduate, graduate, transfer and degree completion, and Threshold programs.

These application guides will give you an overview of the application process. If you're looking for details specific to your program, you can visit any of our program pages and answer a few quick questions to get a customized application guide. And we're always here to help. Our admissions counselors are happy to answer any questions you have at any step along the way. Lesley University deeply values diversity and inclusion in our community and beyond; read our
Policy on Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion.

How to Apply to Lesley's Graduate Programs
Access the application requirements and forms for our master’s degree, PhD, and graduate certificate programs.
Get your graduate program's application requirements here.
Before you can pursue your goals in one of our
master’s degree, PhD, or certificate programs
, you'll need to apply. Our application requirements vary for each program, so here's how you can access your specific program's requirements.
Go to the web page for your academic program and go to the
section. Answer a few questions about where you want to study or if you're a U.S. or international student.

Choose what and where you want to study from the options on this page. Depending on the program, you might study on the Lesley campus, at an off-campus location, online, or in a teacher residency. Select the U.S. or international student requirements for your program.
Only looking for your program's application deadline?
Find all graduate deadlines right here

How to Apply to Lesley's Threshold Program
Follow our step-by-step guide for applying to the two-year Threshold Core Program.
The Threshold Program accepts about 24 new students each year from a large number of applicants. New students are only admitted in September.
We are now accepting applications for Fall 2020.
Submit your online application and the following supporting materials by

Create an online account before you start your application. This account allows you to stop your application and return to complete it later. Once you’ve begun your application, and until you submit it, you can work on it as many times as you want.
Official high school transcript, or certificate of completion.
Evaluations should have been conducted within the past 3 years. Include grade level equivalents that were obtained on one these tests:
Most recent IEP or Section 504 accommodation plan (if applicable)
Tests should have been administered in the past 3 years. The WAIS* is a programmatic requirement. Adaptive Assessments and other types of assessments may be chosen from the list below:
Vineland Adaptive Behavior Rating Scales (VABS) (including the maladaptive subscale)
Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (WAIS) and a full protocol (all sub-test scores and verbal, performance, and full-scale scores) and a written report*

The assessment needs to include a psycho-social history and a combination of psychological tests, and adaptive rating scales. The assessment must be in narrative form and include recommendations for any treatment (psychotherapy or medication) the psychologist finds necessary for the student to function independently in a campus setting.

The goal is to address emotional, behavioral, and social issues that might influence the fit between the student’s needs and the program’s ability to meet those needs. The choice of instruments (the tests listed above) depends on the psychologist’s knowing the student’s cognitive abilities and using appropriate techniques for that student.
Submit three recommendations from people who’ve known the applicant for six or more months. At least one reference should come from a teacher, principal, or guidance counselor.

If possible, one reference should come from an employer or work supervisor. Other possible reference writers include a psychotherapist or social worker. Relatives/family friends are not a suitable reference.
We’ll contact qualified applicants to schedule an interview after we’ve received all of their admissions materials.
